repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Small Scale
            Commercial Agriculture Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Small Scale Commercial
            Agriculture Development Project for Bosnia and Herzegovina
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            project provides the lesson that complex designs, especially
            those with many overlapping activities, are more difficult
            to understand and manage, and measure. Many of the grants
            were awarded to and managed by specialists from one or two
            academic or research institutions, indicating that the
            process was less than competitive. In addition, there was a
            tendency for many grants to be research-driven rather than
            farmer-driven and thus not always entirely responsive in
            addressing the farmers' problems. The development of a
            credit system geared to agricultural producers is difficult
            when a subsidized interest program is also in operation, and
            makes it difficult to encourage modifications in operational
            practices by banks and Mutual Fund Institution's
            (MFIs). The project clearly showed that formation and
            development of cooperatives and associations is a long-term
            undertaking requiring continuing efforts, often longer than
            the project period.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Small Scale
            Commercial Agriculture Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Small Scale Commercial Agriculture
            Development Project for Bosnia and Herzegovina will focus
            activities in the Southeastern part of the country. The area
            has a Mediterranean climate, which is favorable for early
            production of fruit and vegetables, has potential for
            on-farm irrigation resources and continues to have
            traditional trade with neighboring countries. This area was
            impoverished by the war but has the potential to respond
            readily to a revitalization program. The project will 1)
            encourage farmers to adopt more productive and profitable
            production systems and increase the marketability of their
            surplus production; 2) create a dynamic commercial
            agriculture by strengthening linkages among farmers and
            markets through the promotion of private sector investment,
            and credit for farming, agro-processing and trading; 3)
            facilitate the export of agriculture products, through
            information and technical assistance; and 4) support
            measures and investments to strengthen the physical and
            institutional infrastructure of rural communities. The
            project components are: a) market integration; b) private
            agribusiness support; c) commercial farmers development; and
            d) project management. The increased production and
            productivity resulting from the project will increase
            farming and other rural incomes, and reduce unemployment and poverty.

Bosnia and Herzegovina - Small Scale

2009994.trustfund:

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Small Scale
            Commercial Agricultural Development Project : environmental aassessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will develop private,
            market-integrated commercial agriculture in low income,
            though high-potential areas of Bosnia and Herzegovina, thus
            increasing farming, and emphasizing enterprise credit,
            technology development, micro-credit, and irrigation
            rehabilitation. Potential environmental adversity could come
            from agrochemical pollution, and surface water
            contamination, soil erosion, indiscriminate dumping of
            excavated deposits from drains, and structures, and, damage
            caused during construction. Mitigation measures include: a)
            provision of agricultural extension, and advisory services,
            including training for best application techniques of
            fertilizers, and pesticides; b) regular training for
            improved irrigation management practices, to reduce soil
            erosion, and sedimentation on rivers; c) landfills, and dump
            sites will be selected, and, as possible, excavated
            materials will be appropriately disposed of at selected
            disposal sites; precautionary clauses for contractors works
            will be included in the bidding documents, proposing
            rehabilitation, and improvement works; d) monitoring, on the
            use of pesticides, chemicals, and fertilizers will be
            conducted, which will include increased training and
            extension activities, towards reducing the use of inputs as
            possible. Soil erosion will be assessed by Cantonal
            Environment Inspectors (CEIs), and training efforts will be
            intensified as needed. Contractors activities will be
            supervised by the local municipal, or consulting engineers,
            monitored as well by CEIs.
